p: Mosquito-borne viruses driven principally by Aedes aegypti, have emerged and re-emerged globally, resulting in a large burden of human disease [ 1]. Globalization and other anthropogenic factors have allowed this mosquito to thrive in diverse landscapes and facilitate urban transmission cycles of dengue virus (DENV), chikungunya virus (CHIKV), Zika virus (ZIKV), and others [ 2]. In the Americas, all four serotypes of DENV have re-emerged causing consistent epidemics from South America to Mexico and the Caribbean [ 3]. The Asian lineage of CHIKV first arrived in the Caribbean in 2014 and spread throughout the Americas in just a few years [ 4], resulting in 338,963 confirmed human cases [ 5]. ZIKV invaded Brazil in 2013 [ 6] and rapidly swept through the Americas in a similar fashion, resulting in an estimated 8.5 million cases in Brazil alone [ 7].
